plants.name: Rhododendron spp.
plants.description: Rhododendrons are woody shrubs known for their large clusters of showy flowers and glossy evergreen leaves. They thrive in temperate zones and are popular in gardens and wild mountain forests.
plants.location: Temperate regions of North America, Europe, and Asia
plants.funFact: The name 'Rhododendron' means 'rose tree' in Greek, reflecting the rose-like appearance of its flowers.

plants.name: Jacaranda mimosifolia
plants.description: A tropical to subtropical tree famous for its stunning, vibrant violet-blue trumpet-shaped flowers that form panicles covering the tree, creating a spectacular floral display.
plants.location: Native to South America, widely planted in Australia, South Africa, and southern USA
plants.funFact: The Jacaranda tree can live up to 50 years and is a symbol of spring in many cities like Pretoria, South Africa, known as the 'Jacaranda City'.

plants.name: Lupinus spp.
plants.description: Lupines are herbaceous plants or shrubs bearing tall, spike-like clusters of pea-shaped flowers. They fix nitrogen in the soil, improving fertility and are favorite wildflowers in many regions.
plants.funFact: Lupines have specialized root nodules that host nitrogen-fixing bacteria, making them important in ecological restoration.

plants.description: This hybrid magnolia tree produces large, fragrant, tulip-shaped flowers early in spring, often still blooming around late May in cooler climates.
plants.location: Cultivated widely in temperate gardens worldwide
plants.funFact: Magnolias evolved before bees existed and are pollinated primarily by beetles, some of the Earth's oldest pollinators.
